Module simplifier
Package ie.gmit.dip

Class OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • ie.gmit.dip.OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder
  • public class OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder
extends java.lang.Object
    OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder is a concrete class which is used to construct a OneToOneMappedThesaurus from a pair of files, one file containing a thesaurus of words, with synonyms entered as comma separated values on each line, and the other file containing a list of priority words to which words in the thesaurus should be mapped when said priority word is encountered in the thesaurus. Its primary responsibility lies in managing the state and behavior associated with constructing the OneToOneMappedThesaurus. It is composed of two ParsableFile objects, each of which is parsed via a SimpleFileParser type. Data in the priorityWordSetFile is mapped to a HashSet of String types stored in the priorityWordSet variable. Data in the thesaurusFile is mapped to the OneToOneMappedThesaurus type, which is the central object being constructed, and which is stored in the mappedThesaurus variable. The priorityWordSet and the mappedThesaurus are publicly accessible via getter methods. The following important logic applies to this mapper: words in the thesaurus are mapped to a corresponding word in the priorityWordSet on a first-come-first-serve basis, once they have been mapped to an equivalent word, a subsequent equivalent word will not overwrite this initial mapping. This mapper is therefore deterministic based on the order of appearance in the thesaurusFile. A comment on Big-O notation and running times is provided in the buildMappedThesaurus method below. This class is coupled to and cohesive with the Thesaurable interface and OneToOneMappedThesaurus which implements the former. It is also coupled tightly with the ParsableFile type and has multiple dependencies on the SimpleFileParser type. However, the internal behavior which is dependent on ParsableFile is encapsulated and fully shielded from external users of this class, as users simply have to provide standard java File types as input, and ParsableFile types are converted to standard java File types before returning them. In this way, the user of the API can interact with the OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder without understanding or depending on the internal dependency on the ParsableFile and SimpleFileParser types.
    Since:
    JavaSE-11
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Kieran P. Somers
    See Also:
    OneToOneMappedThesaurus, ParsableFile, SimpleFileParser

      • readThesaurusFile

        public void readThesaurusFile()
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Parser method which reads the contents of the thesaurusFile. Responsibility for reading is delegated to a SimpleFileParser with contents stored in the thesaurusFile which is a ParsableFile. Running time is O(c) locally but is O(n) when the SimpleFileParser running time is considered.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if the File or ParsableFile cannot be read or parsed.

      • readPriorityWordSetFile

        public void readPriorityWordSetFile()
                             throws java.lang.Exception
        Parser method which reads the contents of the priorityWordSetFile. Responsibility for reading is delegated to a SimpleFileParser with contents stored in the priorityWordSetFile which is a ParsableFile. Running time is O(c) locally but is O(n) when the SimpleFileParser running time is considered.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if the file cannot be read or parsed.

      • build

        public void build()
           throws java.lang.Exception
        Public method which can be called to construct a new OneToOneMappedThesaurus. Input files are first read in, then the priorityWordSet and OneToOneMappedThesaurus are built. Running time is O(c) locally but is the sum of the running times of the four individual methods being called. The first three method calls are O(n), with the buildMappedThesaurus() method exhibiting cubic O(n^3) scaling in the worst case scenario.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if the file cannot be read or parsed.

      • getPriorityWordSet

        public java.util.HashSet<java.lang.String> getPriorityWordSet()
        Getter method which returns the priorityWordSet as a HashSet of String types. Running time is O(c).
        Returns:
        priorityWordSet a HashSet used to store the contents of the priorityWordSetFile

      • setPriorityWords

        public void setPriorityWords()
        Setter method which builds the priorityWordSet as a HashSet of String types. Running time is O(n) where n is the number of lines in the priorityWordSetFile to be added to the HashSet.

      • buildMappedThesaurus

        public void buildMappedThesaurus()
        Method which builds the OneToOneMappedThesaurus. This method contains specialized/specific logic pertaining to the current project. Specifically, the following logic is enforced: 1) For each line in the thesaurus file, split by commas. 2) If a line contains a word found in the priorityWordSet, set the equivalentWord variable to this word. 3) For each word on the line, remove whitespace and convert to lowercase, then enforce the following logic. 3a) if this word is in the priorityWordSet but not the mappedThesaurus then map it to itself in the mappedThesaurus. 3b) If this word is not in the priorityWordSet but an equivalentWord that is in the priorityWordSet is available, then map the word to the equivalent word if and only if the word has not already been mapped to an equivalent word, or if it has been mapped to itself. 3c) If no equivalent word is available, then map the word to itself, but this self-mapping can be overridden if an equivalent word in the priorityWordSet becomes available on a subsequent line. A comment on Big-O notation is relevant. The outer loop which iterates over the contents of the file has O(n) running time where n is the number of lines in the file. The first inner loop which tests the line for the presence of a word in the "Google 1000" file (i.e. priorityWordSet) has worst-case O(n) running time, as all elements of the line may have to be tested before an equivalent word is found. The second inner loop (not tested with first loop) also runs in O(n) time, but this is compounded by the series of logical if and else if statements, which rely on HashSet and HashMap searches via the contains, hasWord, addWord and getSynonym methods. These latter methods are all dictionary key based operations which have O(1) running time, and are therefore quick. The String.equals() method call which is use to compare equality of two String types has worst-case O(n) running time where n is the length of the String. The running time of this method can be approximate by O(l*n*c) where l is the average number of lines in a file, n is the average number of elements (words) on a line, and c is the average number of characters in an element (word). These might imply an O(n^3) running time in the worst case scenario, however, the number of elements on a line (n) and number of characters in an element (c) are likely to be much less than the number of lines. The use of multiple cheap logic statements to test the thesaurus contents without invoking the expensive equals method, and the use of key based method as frequently as possible should ensure running times are rarely as severe as O(n^3). The actual running time cannot be guaranteed as it depends on the complexity of the thesaurus file provided, and the complexity and order of its contents. In practice, the thesaurus files provided for this project, consisting of 30000 lines, and many more words, can be mapped in less than a second or so.
